Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Miniature, High Temperature, Multiaxial Testing Equipment for Advanced Materials and Engineering Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will enable the development of novel equipment for mechanical testing of miniature tubular specimens under realistic loading conditions by prescribing axial, torsional, and internal pressure loading in a gaseous environment. The equipment will have the capability to vary specimen temperature from ambient to 1000 degrees Celsius and it will be designed to fit under an optical microscope and into scanning electron microscopes for in-situ microstructural studies. The equipment development will be guided by detailed thermo-mechanical analysis. Technologies of actuation, sensing, heating, pressurization, digital image correlation, gripping, and their controls will be investigated for effective integration in developing the equipment. Micro-fabrication and failure life prediction techniques require understanding of material properties and their evolutions, which can only be determined accurately through miniature specimen testing under realistic loading conditions. Miniature specimens can be machined from components in service for testing to estimate remaining life.

This miniature equipment will be shared by a large group of inter and intra university researchers for fundamental research on material design and characterization, micro-forming, integrated computational materials engineering, and failure life prediction for the energy, aerospace, automobile, electronics, biomedical, sensor and infrastructure industries. Emerging research in materials genome for manufacturing resilient components will benefit immensely from this equipment. This equipment will impact design and development of new materials and high-performance components. It will have the potential to reduce the long 10 to 20 year trial and error methods of designing new materials, and to predict component reliability with much less uncertainty than today. Partnership with a US testing equipment manufacturer will facilitate equipment development processes and quick commercialization of the equipment to make it available to other researchers. Through The Engineering Place and Women in Engineering programs at NC State University, K-12 teachers and students will get hands-on experience with the equipment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A novel equipment, named multiaxial miniature testing system (MMTS), was designed and developed for mechanical testing of micro-tubular specimens under realistic loading conditions by prescribing any combination of axial, torsional, and internal pressure loading. In addition, the equipment has the capability to vary specimen temperature within ambient to around 1000?C, and it is designed to fit within a scanning electron microscope (SEM) for in-situ microstructural studies. Such a testing equipment is not commercially available anywhere in the world. Hence, available technologies of actuators, sensors, heating and pressurization, digital image correlation (DIC), water-cooled grips and control systems were critically evaluated for developing technologies for the proposed equipment. Development of the proposed equipment was guided by detailed thermo-mechanical analysis. The load frame, axial-torsional load cell, grippers with the capability of specimen heating and gripper cooling, specimen pressurization system, power system, control systems, SEM stage door and feed-throughs were designed, developed, integrated and checked one by one for proper functionality. Techniques were developed to implement a DIC system to measure strains on curved micro-specimens. Collaborations with U.S. commercial partners, ADMET, Inc., Correlated Solutions, HEPSCO, and UK commercial partner, NovaTech, facilitated the equipment development processes. These partnerships will allow quick commercialization of the equipment to other researchers and engineers.

With emerging research on advanced materials, performing material testing under realistic multiaxial loading at elevated temperatures is an urgent need. For enhancing resilience of manufactured components, design of new materials should consider failure mechanisms at critical locations (weld toe, stress concentration and hot spot) through testing miniature specimen under multiaxial loading. Such tests are needed to be performed at high temperatures for understanding premature failures of components in many industries. Manufacturing processes, such as, welding, cold drawing, quenching, surface finishing etc. induce localized material heterogeneity whose influence on failure mechanism can only be studied through testing micro specimens. Extreme service loading and environmental conditions alter local material properties, which can only be studied through micro specimens in determining remaining life of critical components. Development of micro-fabrication techniques requires material property evolutions, which can only be determined accurately through micro specimen testing under realistic loading.

The developed equipment can be shared by a large group of inter and intra university researchers in performing fundamental research on advanced material design and characterization, micro-forming, material modeling, computational modeling, and failure-life prediction for the energy, aerospace, automobile, electronics, communication, biomedical, sensor and infrastructure industries. The equipment will integrate research activities in material design and component manufacturing through integrating materials and computational modeling research activities. In addition, the proposed equipment will meet the research needs of material characterization performed through standard uniaxial testing systems. The proposed equipment will impact design and development of new materials, high performance components, and micro-forming processes. Another important outcomes will be eliminating the long 10 to 20 years trial & error methods of designing new materials for enhanced component life, and predicting failure life of components with much less uncertainty than today. Two PhD, one MS, and one undergraduate students have been trained in developing miniature testing equipment. Many students will use the equipment in performing their research for MS and PhD degrees. Undergraduate and K-12 students will learn the importance of material testing by using the novel equipment.
